page.title: 15NEWTONMORE, THE VILLAGE 1
page.content: The village of{Newtonmore}has 800 or so inhabitants. It is situated at the south end of the Spey Valley in the centre of the Highlands of Scotland. More than 200 years ago the river was first bridged here to carry the main road from the south into the Highlands to Inverness and eventually , at this point a junction to Fort William, too came into being here. The Name in Gaelic{"Bail Ur an {t-Sleibh",}meaning "the new township on the moor" tells the story of how the village came to be. The earliest householders came from the older townships in{Glen Banchor}above Newtonmore. These families were moved there by forced clearance: being only tenents in the eyes of the law and the proprietor now the "Clan-system" had broken down. Bail Ur an t-Sleibh was a natural place for population growth.
